events.name: Protecting your Android Source
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Out main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature at talk on Protecting your Android Souce by Godfrey Nolan.

Due to the design of the Java Virtual Machine or JVM it is relatively trivial to reverse engineer Java code from Java jar and class files. While this hasn't been an issue in the past since most Java files are hidden on the server, it is an issue on Android phones where the client side Android apk files are easily obtained and just as easy to decompile back into source.

In this talk Godfrey Nolan, author of Decompiling Java, and the soon to be published Decompiling Android will explain how and why this is possible by unraveling the apk into classes.dex files using the tools that are currently available to decompile your apk's back into Java or HTML5/CSS source code with the right click of a mouse. We'll show some of the security issues that this raises, such as inadvertently allowing people gain access to credit card information or backend systems, when someone has complete access to your source. We'll also look at open source and commercial obfuscation tools and other techniques you should be using, such as C++ coding using the NDK, to stop people gaining access to your Android code.

Speaker Bio:
Godfrey Nolan is founder and president of RIIS a mobile development firm in the Detroit Metro area. He is also author of Decompiling Java (Apress) and the soon to be published Decompiling Android. Godfrey has spoken as AnDevCon, JavaOne, ASP-Connections, VSLive, Codemash, Code PaLOUsa, 1DevDay and many local Java and .Net user groups on a wide range of topics such as Continuous Integration, Executable Requirements and mobile security.

events.name: Google I/O Android Recap
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a Google I/O Recap by Michael Pardo and Scott Weber of Mobiata.

This year’s Google I/O favored Android on the whole. Google gave us a new OS, new developer tools, and much more. A lot of attention was paid to design, both visual and architectural. Here’s some of what we, as Android developers, found most valuable.

events.name: Monetizing Android Apps
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a talk on Monetizing Android Apps by Jim Vitek of AppKey.

Android app monetization was a hot topic at both Google I/O and AnDevCon. This session will recap monetization topic highlights from these conferences, discuss how to decide on the best model for your app, and demonstrate the integration process for 2 ad-supported models (admob and AppKey)

events.name: Getting started with Android Library Projects
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a talk on getting started with Android Library Projects by Jeff McWherter of Gravity Works Design and Development.

As a great software developer, you learned early in your development career that duplication of code was not a good idea. With development patterns such as SOLID, developers are trained early that code duplication is evil.

To help avoid code duplication, and allow parts of Android applications to be reusable, the Android platform has recently introduced library projects to add to your development arsenal to help battle these issues. In this session, we will explore Android library projects and the benefit they can provide to your application.

Jeff McWherter is the Director of Development at Gravity Works Design and Development. Jeff graduated from Michigan State University with a degree in Telecommunications, and has fourteen years of professional experience in software development. He is a founding member of the Greater Lansing Users for .NET.

He enjoys profiling code, applying design patterns, finding obscure namespaces, and long walks in the park. His lifelong interest in programming began with a Home Computing Magazine in 1983, which included an article about writing a game called Boa Alley in BASIC. Jeff currently lives in a farming community near Lansing, MI. When he is not in front of the computer he enjoys rock and ice climbing with his smart and beautiful wife; which leads to his favorite activity of all, road trips.

events.name: Introduction to Android Development with Java -- HTML5 need not apply.
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature an Introduction to Android Development in Java by Dan McNeil of Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Whether you have a deep understanding of Java or are just getting started with the language, the Open Source Platform that is Android is an easy, quick and Mostly Free(!) way to get started developing software in the mobile world!

In this session, we will learn about the tools, documentation and basic testing abilities that can be had for Free(!) and how to get started using them to develop applications that can range from trivial (fart apps, right?) to the (extremely) non-trivial.

Dan McNeil is the Lead Android Developer for Arbormoon Software, Inc.  His passion for Android began when he tried to install Android Beta on a Treo 650 only to find it needed more RAM to be fun, and has not stopped since.

events.name: Android Design Guidelines: The missing pages
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Resort Advantage.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a talk on Android Design Guidelines: The missing pages by Tricia Cervenan of Quicken Loans.

Tricia Cervenan is responsible for Mobile Marketing at Quicken Loans, and has worked with the Quicken Loans team to build a number of mobile applications.  Along the way she has dug deep into the Android Design Guidelines to try to build best in class Android applications. Come hear what she has learned along the way. While Tricia won't be showing code, she has alot of experience helping guide developers, and this talk is intended to help coders and non coders alike advance the user experience of apps on Android.

events.name: Animations in Android
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a talk on Animations in Android by Scott Weber of Mobiata.

This talk will take a look at the various ways to animate views in Android, focusing mostly on the use of Animators which were introduced in Honeycomb, but are available on older platforms thanks the the Nine Old Androids library.  In addition to covering the basics, it will also consider some caveats and lessons learned from adding animations to our apps at Mobiata.

If you like, you can check out the following apps to get a taste of what we will be looking at: FlightTrack Free, Expedia Hotels & Flights and Nine Old Androids Sample.

events.name: Database Introduction with SQLite
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a Database Introduction with SQLite talk by Dean-O Rochester

Android, Blackberry, iPhone and Palm support using an embedded database known as  SQLite We will go through a basic example that will show you how to integrate an SQLite database into your application.
Things you will need:

SQLite software to create the database comes standard on intel macs free needs to be downloaded for windows SQLite browser/editor software used to create/edit databases and tables free needs to be downloaded and set up Create a simple database and table Create Android Database sample application Put database into Android project Test app (fingers crossed, hope all goes well)  :) Dean-O is a Programmer Analyst for a health care system in Ohio by day, and after hours he is an independent app developer.  In addition, he is Adjunct Faculty at BGSU and Owens Community College teaching programming related courses including java curriculum and smart phone programming.

events.name: Don't Root Robots: Breaks in Google's Android platform
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by TechSmith

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature Don't Root Robots: Breaks in Google's Android platform talk by Jon Oberheide, CTO of Duo Security.

In this talk, we'll dive into the many public breaks of Google's Android platform, from the base system and kernel, the platform middleware, and the third-party applications. As Android emerges as a leading OS in the mobile market, there's much to be learned from both the victories and failures of Google's design decisions and their impact on Android's security model. We'll show off some fun attacks used to subvert the base Android system as well as third-party applications in use on Android handsets around the world.

Jon Oberheide is CTO of Duo Security, an Ann Arbor-based startup focused on two-factor authentication and mobile security. In his free time, Jon dabbles in kernel exploitation, abusing Android devices, and beer brewing.

events.name: Adapters: Bringing data into view
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by TechSmith

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a talk on Adapters: Bringing data into view by Joseph Blough of Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Adapters are used to connect collections of information with user interface elements (ListViews, ViewPagers, etc).  This talk will go over the different kinds of adapters, basic use, customization of the presentation, and the ViewHolder pattern.

Joseph Blough is a Senior Software Engineer at Arbormoon Software, Inc focused on building Android Apps.

events.name: I/O Extended Ann Arbor
events.description:
Come hang out with other Android developers and watch the live stream of Google I/O Android events.  More details will be announced as Google posts more details.

We'll start with the keynote on Wednesday at noon, and switch to various Android sessions throughout the remainder of the conference.

Where there are conflicts, we'll probably focus more on non game sessions, but we're open to some input depending on who shows up.

Feel free to pop in and out.  We'll have some tables setup, and you can just hang out with your laptop.

events.name: Google I/O Recap
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a recap of the recent Google I/O conference by members that attended in person or via the Google I/O Extended. Rather than a presentation, this meeting will be run more as an interactive discussion, lead by Scott Weber of Mobiata.

We would love for everyone who would like to share something new and/or interesting that they learned either during the event or simply reviewing YouTube videos afterward to participate.

If you are able to assist in co-recapping, you may contact one of the organizers to coordinate.  Or you can just show up and join the discussion!

events.name: Android Custom Views, the Right Way
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a presentation by Michael Pardo on Android Custom Views, the Right Way.

Android is a very powerful framework that has just about everything you’ll need out of the box. For everything else, Android includes a sophisticated and powerful framework for creating the crazy UI you have in mind. Learn the three main methods we use to create custom views, and all the tips you’ll need to write code that fits right in with the Android Open Source Project.

Michael is a software engineer working in Ann Arbor, Michigan, writing Android apps at Mobiata, an Expedia company. He writes an open source active record style ORM for Android called ActiveAndroid – easily persisting objects to SQLite databases. Michael is the author of RingDimmer – a featured Android app that sets your ring volume to the room volume.

events.name: Understanding user behavior with analytics + Google Glass
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, include a brief show and tell of Google Glass and a presentation by Jim Vitek on Mobile App Analytics.

Developers love to create apps for others to use and enjoy. It is rewarding to watch the first few users interact with your app. But how about the second hundred? thousand? million? How do you know if they even open your app if you don’t measure usage?

Mobile App Analytics is a powerful free tool based on Google Analytics. Integrating analytics is easy and will help you understand how ALL users use your app, and help you prioritize features better than ever before. The presentation will walk through a demo integration and show how usage data can be explored on the GA web interface. Also covered will be exception reporting and an overview of NanoGA, an open source library that interfaces directly with the GA Measurement Protocol without need for the SDK.

Jim is an Android developer, and founder/CEO of AppKey.

events.name: Android Debugging
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm and feature a presentation by David Wang on Android Debugging.

Everyone knows that debugging software is hard.  Whether it be logcat, toasting diagnostics to the screen, or even using the debugger, Android gives us tools to help deal with those bugs.  This talk will be an introduction to those tools, along with some tips and tricks to make our debugging lives just a little bit easier.

events.name: Android Widgets
events.description:
PLEASE NOTE THE LOCATION CHANGE FROM OUR USUAL MEETING SPOT!

Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm. Keith Bourne and Melissa Benzie of Arbormoon Software will go in-depth into the world of widgets, from strategy to practical implementation. App Widgets are miniature application views that can be embedded in other applications (such as the home screen) and receive periodic updates. Widgets are extensions of your app that provide a whole new level of creative freedom and functionality that aren't even available on that "other" platform. Join us and learn about this exciting aspect of the Android platform. 

Melissa Benzie, Senior Sofware Engineer at Arbormoon Software - Melissa has many years of experience developing applications for a variety of industries including automotive, manufacturing, marketing, technology, and medical companies.  She is currently developing mobile apps on Android and iOS platforms for Arbormoon.

Keith Bourne, Lead Mobile Strategist for Arbormoon Software - Keith got into mobile in the 90’s when everyone else was chasing Internet companies. Because of this, he is one of the most experienced mobile strategy professionals in the field. Over the years, he built and refined his expertise in launching new businesses, new products, and strategically driving the growth of companies he is involved with, often into triple digit revenue growth within months. He has deep knowledge in the breadth of areas that makes launching new ventures and product lines successful – marketing, technology development and deployment, product innovation, brand management, business development, sales and field work management and support, relationship management, operational improvements, and revenue generation. Keith is co-founder of multiple network groups, including the Michigan chapter of Mobile Monday, which has grown to 4 chapters and over 2,500 members in just three years.

events.name: Agile Android
events.description:
PLEASE NOTE: LOCATION IS SAME AS LAST MONTH, BUT DIFFERENT FROM USUAL.

Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm.

Topic: Agile Android by Godfrey Nolan

There's no reason why agile practices and Android can't go hand in hand. Learn how to add TDD (test driven-development, or unit tests) and BDD (behavior-driven development, or functional tests), as well as continuous integration environments, to your next Android project. Using Robolectric, Calabash and a Jenkins server, this class will walk you through how to quickly get started with adding agile best practices to your Android projects.

Godfrey is founder and president of RIIS, a mobile development firm in the Detroit Metro area. He is also author of “Decompiling Java” (Apress) and “Decompiling Android.” Godfrey has spoken at JavaOne, ASP-Connections, VSLive, Codemash, Code PaLOUsa, 1DevDay, and many local Java and .NET user groups.

events.name: Consuming Web Services with Android
events.description:
PLEASE NOTE: WE ARE BACK AT ARBORMOON THIS MONTH!

Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm.

Topic: Consuming Web Services with Android by Dave Truxall

As mobile apps continue to get more sophisticated, they need data, whether it’s from the business backend or the current scoreboard for a game server hosted in the cloud. Find out how to connect to and consume web services with your Android application, and how to avoid common pitfalls. We’ll get connected to the cloud, working with REST web services and learning how to parse the results.


About the speaker

Dr. Truxall has been programming for a living since 1995, working previously with enterprise technologies modeling internal business processes and building public web sites. Now he is working as a mobile architect, bringing mobile apps to the enterprise. He is currently employed by Compuware in Detroit. He is a co-author of the upcoming Apress book Android Best Practices.

events.name: Share a Tip Night
events.description:
New Location! Arbormoon Software has moved, and so has the meeting. 123 N Ashley, Suite 9, on the lower level is the new location.

Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm. 

Topic: Share a Tip / Trick Night! by Everybody!

Everyone gathers his or her own toolbox of tips and tricks while learning and using any set of tools.  They could be a collection of helpful resources, a better way to use a stock tool, a hidden feature in a development environment, a cool new utility, the "right way" to implement some feature, etc.  At this meeting, we will give the floor to anyone who wants to share a tip or trick about Android development with the rest of the group.  Tips from anyone and everyone are encouraged, whether you're just getting started, have been developing since the G1 or anywhere in between.  We would expect most to take just a few minutes to share and we'll keep taking presenters until we run out of time.

Some ideas:

• An introduction to a tool or library that you find particularly useful

• A list of resources (sites, books, tutorials, examples, etc.) that you found useful for learning Android Dev

• Tips for setting up a publishing account on Google Play

• Your experience from publishing an app on Google Play

• A list of blogs/sites/people that you follow for Android Dev tips

• A performance pitfall and how to avoid it

• Utility methods/classes that you have created or found that make your life easier

• Anti-tips: Mistakes that you have discovered the hard way

• Testing practices that you have found valuable

events.name: Beginning Android: Pitfalls and Roadblocks
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm. 

Google's Android is a great platform for developers, but is not without its share of "gotchas." iOS developer and amateur Android developer Hung Truong will walk through some of the common pitfalls and roadblocks he faced on his way to releasing his first Android app. These include: Android Permissions, Simulator, Fragments, and more!

events.name: Effective Use of the Volley Networking Library
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm.

Announced and released at Google I/O 2013, Volley is a powerful library that makes common, complex networking tasks vastly simpler. Even better, it is highly customizable and extendable, allowing for plenty of flexibility to work with your app's requirements. Unfortunately, there is not a lot of great documentation on how to use Volley, especially when you get past the most basic use cases. At Mobiata, Volley played a central role in the re-architecture of FlightTrack in 2013. Scott Weber, lead developer on the project, will show you how to get started with Volley and how to leverage its power to go beyond just loading images from the network.

events.name: Android Short Talks
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and will feature three short talks.

Recording Demos with Kit Kat's screen record feature

Learn how to record a demo video of your Android app without a video camera!  Keith Bourne will walk through the steps of using Android Development Bridge to record an app demo video directly on your device through Kit Kat's (4.4) new screenrecord feature.  He will add tips and tricks along the way to prepare the demo videos you record for promotional or education use.

In-App Purchase and Billing

Todd DeLand will present a quick overview of in-app billing concepts (a few slides), workflow, plus some code that is in his Auto Volume app. He will show a test transaction from beginning to end, and view the transaction in the Google Wallet Merchant account.

Todd DeLand is a software engineer, photographer, and father from Ann Arbor. He works at Above The Treeline and in his spare time on various Android projects. He enjoys keeping up on technology and finding ways to integrate it with daily life.


Supporting Synchronous Collaboration in Mobile Apps: Use Collabrify.IT’s SDK to Collabrify YOUR App!

Starting out in the K-12 space, we built an SDK to collabrify – enable mobile apps on iOS and Android to support the simultaneous use by two or more individuals who need not be co-located – educational apps such as concept mapping, KWL charting, drawing/animation, writing, etc. We have now generalized the SDK, started Collabrify.IT, Inc., and are looking to license the Collabrify SDK to iOS and Android mobile app developers.

In our presentation, we will demo a collabrified app (WeList, a collabrified list making app), describe the architecture of the underlying collabrification system, and show code snippets for how to actually collabrify an app. Our primary intent in giving this presentation isn’t sales, but rather we are looking for feedback from developers on our collabrification technique/architecture.

Presenting will be Elliot Soloway, CEO and UMich Professor, Kevin Crosby, Josh Lin (RPM Associate), Vidal Borromeo, Josh Meyer, Adrian Prayogo.

For more information visit: http://collabrify.it/  and http://www.intergalacticmlc.org/ or contact [masked]  For pictures of the presenters see: http://collabrify.it/about/

events.name: The Michigan Google Developers DevFest 2014
events.description:
The Detroit and Ann Arbor Chapters of the Google Developers Group (GDG) are hosting a one day Google DevFest in Downtown Detroit. The DevFest will focus on two tracks - one on Android development and one on Google Web Technology. Checkout the website for all the details.

This event requires the purchase of a ticket for entry in order to help us cover the costs of the event. You must register via the EventBrite page in order to attend.

events.name: Android Wearables
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food. Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and will feature a short talk on Android Wearables, followed by Code Lab. Google has indicated a limited number of vouchers for physical devices may be available. More details when we get them.

Sorry this is an non standard week for us, but we were waiting on a slide deck from Google...

UPDATE: The slide deck is now in and we are looking forward to going over all the info with you on Thursday.

In the meantime, we have some pre-event prep for you!  The more you do, the more you'll get out of the event!  You'll definitely want to do these soon if you want to participate in the Code Lab.  Here you go:

• You really want to do this ASAP, takes up to 24 hours to get approved: Sign up for the developer preview: http://developer.android.com/wear/preview/signup.html 

NOTE: It takes up 24 hours to get approved.  After registration, you should get a confirmation email that includes a link to the Android Wear Developer Preview support library and a link to opt-in to the Android Wear Preview app beta distribution in Google Play store.

• Get the whole Android Wear Developer Preview set up, see more steps below.

• Use the #AndroidWear to post to social media during the event - see what happens...

• Post your Android Wear app ideas and screenshots to the public G+ community: g.co/androidweardev  

• Join the +Android Wear Developers community: g.co/androidweardev

• Check out the YouTube videos for Android Wear DevByte playlist

• Bring an Android phone or tablet to the event for testing your app.

• Set up Android Studio:  Download Android Studio from: http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/studio.html

Android Wear Developer Preview Setup

• Follow steps outlined in the “Get Started with the Developer Preview” page

• Prerequisites

• Install the Android Wear System Image

• Set up the Android Wear Emulator

• Set up the Android Wear Preview App

• Add the Support Library to Your Project

• Try Android Wear code samples available in the Android Wear Developer Preview

• WearableNotificationsSample

• ElizaChat

• RecipeAssistant

events.name: Google I/O Extended Ann Arbor
events.description:
Come hang out with other Android developers and watch the live stream of Google I/O Android events. More details will be announced as Google posts more details.

We'll start with the keynote on Wednesday at noon, and switch to various Android sessions throughout the remainder of the conference.

Where there are conflicts, we'll probably focus more on non game sessions, but we're open to some input depending on who shows up.

Feel free to pop in and out. We'll have some tables setup, and you can just hang out with your laptop.

events.name: Google I/O Show & Tell
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a recap of the recent Google I/O conference by members that attended in person, and a hands-on Show & Tell of the various technologies featured at the conference. Rather than a presentation, this meeting will be run more as an interactive round table discussion co-led by Jim Vitek & David Wang. We will have the official swag from I/O to play with, including several Android Wear watches, devices running the L preview, #cardboard, and the material design guide.

We would love for everyone to participate. If you have built something with any of the newly announced API’s, please contact Jim.Vitek (at gmail) so we can reserve time during the “show & tell”.

events.name: Demo Night
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and will feature demos from various Android developers in the community. Members of this group are behind dozens of published android apps. Whether you built the whole app yourself, or were responsible for a small part, please come and show off your work for 5-10 minutes this Thursday. Both self-published & work-for-hire apps are welcome.

Demos 

#1 - Voltset - World’s Smartest Multimeter for Smart Devices

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/tomwang/voltset-worlds-smartest-multimeter-for-smart-devic

#2 - PAUSE - Availability Management Made Easy - http://pauselabs.com/ 

#3 - Living the 7 Habits

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.livingthe7habits.phone.android

#4 - Zombie Wonderland 2 (Unity3d game with native Android extensions)

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.twistedoak.zw2

Demo format:

- 5m Q&A

We have room for one more demo. Please contact the organizers via meetup, email, or at the pre-meeting to reserve a spot. 

Note - As you may have noticed, this is a change from the previously posted Android TV topic. We are still planning an Android TV meetup, but were not able to coordinate a device and a speaker on this date. Please stay tuned for the reschedule.

events.name: Android Data
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. The main event will start at 7pm: hot off his presentation at Droidcon NYC, Michael Pardo will share with us his talk on Android Data. Android gives you several options to store your data, and the Android community gives you even more. This talk will cover the many different data storage options available to you and the reasons you might choose one over the other. We'll look at implementation details, common pitfalls, and examples of how you might use each in the real world.

Michael Pardo is a software engineer working in Ann Arbor, Michigan, writing Android apps at Lift. He also writes an active record style ORM for Android called ActiveAndroid. ActiveAndroid allows you to easily persist objects to SQLite databases in Android. He is the author of RingDimmer — an Android app that sets your ring volume to the room volume — and Quotes — a simple, Holo themed stock quote tracker.

events.name: Connect with UMSI!
events.description:
Greetings from the University of Michigan School of Information (UMSI)!

At UMSI, we create and share knowledge so that people will use information -- with technology -- to build a better world. Students interested in a graduate degree can receive a Ph.D. in Information, a Master of Science in Information, or a Master of Health Informatics (a joint program with the School of Public Health).

With a 99% job placement rate, UMSI students are prepared for impactful jobs in many industries (see https://si.umich.edu/careers/si-salaries for more information).

Want to learn more or know someone who does?

Come to Connect with UMSI, informative sessions for prospective Master's and PhD students:

· Thursday, October 16 (5:30-7:45 p.m.): learn about academic programs, admissions, funding, and career development in a shorter version of our Saturday event

· Saturday, October 18 (1:30-5:00 p.m.): engage with faculty and current students and learn in-depth about academic programs, admissions, funding, and career development

Both Connect with UMSI events will be held in Palmer Commons in Ann Arbor, MI, just a short walk away from North Quad, where UMSI classes are held. Click here for more information and to RSVP: https://www.si.umich.edu/academics/connect-umsi. Prospective students are welcome at one or both sessions depending on availability and interest in the program.

Students interested in the Master of Health Informatics, a joint program with the School of Public Health, are invited to MHI Prospective Student Day, Saturday, November 8 (1:00-5:00 p.m.) and can learn more and register here: http://healthinformatics.umich.edu/events/mhi-prospective-student-day. MHI Prospective Student Day will be held in North Quad in Ann Arbor, MI.

We look forward to seeing you at one of these events!

events.name: Learning Android Development with Udacity + Android TV
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by TEKsystems. The main event will start at 7pm.

Joe Glandorf will present two talks, the first on his experience with completing the online course "Developing Android Apps", from Udacity and co-developed with Google.  The course guides you through the design and implementation of an Android app while covering activities, fragments, layouts, threading, permissions, intents, content providers, loaders, adapters, services, and notifications, and encourages completion of your own final project. 

The second talk will be an introduction to Android TV.  What it is; the conceptual,  visual, and hardware differences between phone/tablet and Android TV; implementation guidelines for Android TV apps; code and live demos.

Joe Glandorf is a contract software engineer in Ann Arbor, who has worked in the infotainment, CNC, and resistance welding industries.  He holds amateur radio license AC8ES.

events.name: Holiday meetup
events.description:
Bring your projects, bring your questions, and come hang out. 

Our normal cycle (last Thursday of the month) falls on Christmas day this year. So instead of just canceling like the grinch, we're going to meet casually @Grizzly Peak on the 18th to talk lollipops, gingerbread, and anything else Android. Please RSVP so we can provide an accurate count.

events.name: Integrating Dropbox into Android apps
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm.

Our speaker this month is Tim Burnham. Tim will demo "Setlist Helper and Songbook" and show how it uses Dropbox. It will be followed by an overview of the various ways that dropbox can be implemented into Android. A code walkthrough of implementing the Dropbox Core API will be shown and sample code will be provided.

Tim Burnham is the creator of "Setlist Helper and Songbook" and companion site <a>http://www.setlisthelper.com.</a> He is a full stack developer with over 14 years of commercial software experience, and currently a Principle Software Developer for Symantec. He received a Bachelors degree in Computer Information Systems from Eastern Michigan University.

events.description:

We'll be starting out with getting everyone set up with Android Studio and Udacity. Please bring your computer so you can follow along with us.

Before attending, please have Java and Android Studio downloaded and installed. That way, we won't have to wait for everyone to download it.

http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html

Here's a link to the Udacity course we'll be using:

https://www.udacity.com/course/ud853

events.name: Udacity Study Jam - Lesson 1
events.description:
NOTICE OF CHANGE:
The meetup now starts at 6 pm to better accommodate more students.

Welcome to the only Study Jam in Michigan! We're now listed on Google's Study Jam website, so if you haven't seen it for yourself yet, head on over to http://developerstudyjams.com/ and check it out.

A few orders of business first. If you haven't signed up for a Udacity account, please do so. Once you have a Udacity account, make sure you sign up for the StudyJam group at this link: https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/StudyJam

If you're on Google+, you can join the global Study Jam community here: https://plus.google.com/communities/107779414017676143474

Finally, there was interest in starting a collaborative forum for students, so I've created a Google Group that is open to the public: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/gdg-a3-study-jam

This is a meetup series that will go through the Android Fundamentals course on Udacity. (https://www.udacity.com/course/ud853) We meet every Wednesday night at 6 pm from now until the end of March. For each week, you should have that week's lesson completed. (For this meetup, you should have lesson 1 completed) We'll spend about 30 minutes at the beginning going over lesson 1's material, with a chance for students to ask questions. Afterwards, the rest of the time will be free time for students to work on their own projects, and we'll play the course videos on the big screen as well.

If there are any questions, please don't hesitate to ask. I had notifications turned off somehow last week, but I'll be checking the comments manually as well this week.

P.S. If there's interest, we can definitely order some pizzas to keep the jam going...

events.name: Udacity Study Jam - Lesson 2
events.description:
NOTICE OF CHANGE:

A reminder that we have a Google Group that has more information, so please check it out if you haven't. https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/gdg-a3-study-jam

events.name: Share a Tip Night
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm. Topic: Share a Tip / Trick Night! by Everybody!

Everyone gathers his or her own toolbox of tips and tricks while learning and using any set of tools. They could be a collection of helpful resources, a better way to use a stock tool, a hidden feature in a development environment, a cool new utility, the "right way" to implement some feature, etc. At this meeting, we will give the floor to anyone who wants to share a tip or trick about Android development with the rest of the group. Tips from anyone and everyone are encouraged, whether you're just getting started, have been developing since the G1 or anywhere in between. We would expect most to take just a few minutes to share and we'll keep taking presenters until we run out of time.

Some ideas:

• An introduction to a tool or library that you find particularly useful
• A list of resources (sites, books, tutorials, examples, etc.) that you found useful for learning Android Dev
• Tips for setting up a publishing account on Google Play

• Your experience from publishing an app on Google Play
• A list of blogs/sites/people that you follow for Android Dev tips
• A performance pitfall and how to avoid it

• Utility methods/classes that you have created or found that make your life easier
• Anti-tips: Mistakes that you have discovered the hard way
• Testing practices that you have found valuable

events.name: Dead Simple Push Messaging with Parse.com
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Our main meeting will start at 7pm. Topic: Dead Simple Push Messaging with Parse.com presented by Scott Weber.

Push messaging can seem a bit overwhelming at first glance. You have to build out a server component, gather a bunch of keys, create a receiver, register with Google, and then hope (fingers crossed!) that you got all the moving parts hooked together in the right way and that push message shows up on your device.

Parse.com to the rescue! Using the free tools from Parse.com, you can get up and running with push messaging in your app in a matter of minutes. A couple of clicks on a website, a few lines of code and you're off and running.

In this presentation, we will build a brand new app, enable push messaging via Parse.com, and successfully deliver push messages to that app. Feel free to bring your laptop and follow along to push-enable your own app, if you like!

---------------

Scott Weber is an Android developer at Expedia in Ann Arbor.

events.name: Adaptive Android Design Practice
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc. Please RSVP to help us estimate how much food we need. While you are enjoying the food, talk with other developers and network in the local Android community. 

Our main meeting will start at 7pm and will feature a talk on Adaptive Android Design Practice. In this talk, we will talk about how to create deliverable and adaptive design for Android apps from scratch. We will cover pretty much everything practical from looking for design resources to generating correct Specs and image sizes based on device sizes and densities . From this talk, you will also gain insights into the differences between iOS and Android in terms of design and implementations.

Ni Yan has a background of Journalism and Communication in Beijing Normal University, and she got a master degree in Human Computer Interaction and Social Computing at University of Michigan School of Information. Ni is always driven by her artistic nature and passion of creativity. With experience working in several tech startups and projects, she loves entrepreneurial spirit, innovation, team-working, rapid iterations, prototyping, and front-end developing. She is especially passionate in designing and developing mobile and web apps for education, games for good, healthcare and motion-sensing technologies. 

David Wang gave up PHP and started developing Android apps in 2010, and hasn't looked back. He's worked on many apps from small to large, with a passion for Android-based design, convincing clients to give up their iOS designs in favor of Holo, and more recently, Material.

events.name: Michigan GDG DevFest 2015
events.description:
Join us for a full day of Android and Google technologies! Check out the event website for the schedule of events and more details: michigandevfest.com

Then head over to purchase a ticket. ($50 for Professionals, $25 for Students)

Please note that this event requires that you purchase a ticket. An RSVP on Meetup is not sufficient.

events.name: Google I/O Extended
events.description:
Come hang out with other Android developers and watch the live stream of Google I/O Android events. Google has agreed to sponsor the event, so we will have food and drinks for the lunch, and dinner both days!  Plus we may have some extra $ for swag.

We'll start with the keynote on Thursday at noon, and switch to various Android sessions throughout the remainder of the conference. The event will take place both Thursday from noon - 8pm, and Friday from noon - 9pm. More details will be announced as Google posts more details.

Where there are conflicts, we'll probably focus more on non game sessions, but we're open to some input depending on who shows up.

Feel free to pop in and out. We'll have some tables setup, and you can just hang out with your laptop.

events.name: Google I/O Recap
events.description:
Starting at 6:30pm, we'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

Our main meeting will start at 7pm, and feature a recap of the recent Google I/O conference by members that attended in person or via the Google I/O Extended. Rather than a presentation, this meeting will be run more as an interactive discussion, lead by Scott Weber of Mobiata.

We would love for everyone who would like to share something new and/or interesting that they learned either during the event or simply reviewing YouTube videos afterward to participate.

If you are able to assist in co-recapping, you may contact one of the organizers to coordinate.  Or you can just show up and join the discussion!

events.name: Android Performance Workshop
events.description:
We're going to change up our usual format a bit this month, spending the evening hands-on with tools and techniques for making sure your app's performance is where it ought to be!

We'll have free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software and plenty of seats at the table. Bring your laptop, your devices, and your questions.

It will be an open forum for folks to work side-by-side, asking questions, helping each other, and learning along the way. While performance may be the main idea for the night, feel free to stop by with your projects, questions, and thoughts to share with the group, whatever they may be.

Looking for some inspiration? Check out the excellent series of videos from Google: Android Performance Patterns

events.name: Android Wear Watch Face Code Lab
events.description:
Join us for a hands-on evening as we all learn how to build a custom watch face for Android Wear! Bring your laptop and devices, if you've got 'em. If you don't, come by and pair up! An Android Wear device is not required, as we'll setup emulators as needed.

There'll be free food sponsored by Arbormoon Software and plenty of seats at the table.

events.name: Droidcon NYC Highlights
events.description:
Droidcon NYC 2015 was held at the end of August. The two day event included presentations from dozens of the top names in Android development, including Southeast Michigan's own Godfrey Nolan and Michael Pardo. Whether you were able to attend in person or not, there is a ton of content to sort through to find the best, most valuable information, tips, and tricks. This month, Kevin Carpenter will help do just that. He was able to attend Droidcon NYC in person this year and will present a run down of the important take-aways from the event.

Starting at 6:30pm, we will have free food, sponsored by Arbormoon Software. The main event will begin at 7:00pm.

Kevin Carpenter currently works on the Android client at Notion AI in Ann Arbor, MI.

events.name: Android Test Driven Development
events.description:
There’s no reason why Agile practices and Android can’t go hand in hand. Join us and learn how to add TDD (test driven development) to your next Android project. Thankfully, you no longer have to rely on Google’s jUnit3 testing framework now that Google have rolled out jUnit4 testing in Android Studio. The session begins with how to set up Android Studio to do unit tests and mocking. We then move on to use unit testing to create a sample app to show best practices for creating a test-driven Environment.

We'll start at 6:30 with food sponsored by Arbormoon Software. The presentation will begin at 7:00.

A little bit about this month's presenter:

Godfrey Nolan is founder and president of RIIS LLC, a mobile development firm in the Detroit Metro area. He is also author of "Bulletproof Android," "Android Best Practices," "Decompiling Java" and "Decompiling Android." Godfrey has spoken at several AnDevcons as well as DroidCon, JavaOne, ASP-Connections, VSLive, Codemash, Code PaLOUsa, 1DevDay and many local Java and .Net user groups on a wide range of topics such as Continuous Integration, Automated Testing and mobile security.

events.name: Kotlin: New Hope in a Java 6 Wasteland
events.description:
Java 8 was released last year adding lambdas, streams, and many other language improvements. Java 9 is already in the works, but with over half of Android devices stuck using Java 6 will we ever get to use a modern language?

Introducing Kotlin: a statically typed JVM language backed by JetBrains. With features like lambdas, class extensions, and null-safety, it aims to be concise, expressive, and highly interoperable. In this presentation we will learn how powerful Kotlin can be when added to your Android tool belt.

The meetup will start at 6:30 with food sponsored by Arbormoon Software. The presentation will begin at 7:00.

This month's presenter is Michael Pardo of Notion.

events.name: Plotting TheRide bus data on Google Maps
events.description:
This month Todd DeLand will give a quick demo of his app Ann Arbor Bus Locator, which uses data from the Ann Arbor Area Transportation Authority (TheRide) and Google Maps. After the demo, he will show how to get started with Google Maps using the latest Google APIs for Android and plotting some data. 

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.


About the presenter

Todd DeLand is a software engineer, and father from Ann Arbor. He works at Above the Treeline primarily using .NET, and in his spare time on various Android projects. He enjoys keeping up on technology and finding ways to integrate it with daily life.

events.name: Study Jam - Android for Beginners
events.description:
It's Study Jam time again! This season, we'll be using Udacity's Android Development for Beginners. The course is geared towards people new to Android development, as well as people new to programming in general, so don't worry if you're new to all of this.

We'll have a new format this time as well. We'll have meetups every 1st and 3rd Thursday of the month, from Feb 4 until April 21, and we'll have time set aside for watching the lesson videos together, as well as time for you to work on your project alongside fellow students. We'll have at least one person who has completed the course in attendance, so they'll be able to help answer questions you might have. As an incentive, we'll be providing a limited number of swag kits for people who finish the course with us!

This first session, we'll watch a live hangout with the course instructors, which will start at 6pm sharp! (This is why the start time is 5:45) Afterwards, we'll help get everyone set up with Java and Android Studio, and either get the emulator working, or connect their Android device for development.

If you want to get a head start, you can download Android Studio and the Android SDK here. Note that you'll need to install a copy of the JDK as well, which is available here. Finally, and most importantly, sign up for the Google Study Jams group on Udacity here.

events.name: Study Jam - Android for Beginners
events.description:
We're back this week with another session of the Android for Beginners Study Jam. If you missed the first one, don't sweat it, as we're going to start the actual lessons at this session. You don't need to have Android Studio installed, because the first few lessons are done all online in the browser.

We'll start with pizza, and then there will be a short intro, and then we'll get right into the lessons.

Take a look at the website, and make sure you register for the Study Jams. http://developerstudyjams.com/

Other than that, we'll see you on Thursday!

events.name: Android Security
events.description:
This month Gilad Pagi will give a talk on Android Security. As a popular open source operating system, Android faces a great security challenge. It must act as a secure platform while revealing its code to the public eyes. Therefore, Android implements various security concepts and mechanisms. In this talk we will go over the main security concepts and demonstrate the implementation: Android sandboxing, Permission architecture, Application packaging and signing, Shell access capabilities, and Implications of "rooting" a device.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

About the presenter

Gilad Pagi is a summa cum laude graduate of the Technion - Israel Institute of Technology. Gilad acquired his B.S. in Math, and B.S. + M.S. in Engineering before joining a research and development team, first as an engineer and then as an R&D team leader. After seven years, Gilad moved to Michigan and founded "GP Group" a cyber technology consulting company. He is currently pursuing his PhD in Mathematics at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor.

events.name: Study Jam - Android for Beginners
events.description:
Sorry for the late update, but we're back this week with another session of the Android for Beginners Study Jam. This week, we'll be taking it easy with an "office hours" session, where there won't be a formal lesson, and people can work on their things and get help at their own pace.

Feel free to come anytime, but the pizza will be colder the longer you wait. ;)

Take a look at the website, and make sure you register for the Study Jams. http://developerstudyjams.com/

Other than that, we'll see you on Thursday!

events.name: Study Jam - Android for Beginners
events.description:
Sorry for the late update (again), but we're back this week with another session of the Android for Beginners Study Jam. This week, we'll be holding a more formal study group, since there are only three more meetups. 

We'll be reviewing all the material covered in Lesson 1, and if there are any people who need help with Android Studio, you can get help with that too. If you've already completed Lesson 1, or you just want to work on your own, please feel free to do so. We'll be moving on to Lesson 2 very soon.

We're excited to open the submission process for T-shirts. Everyone who comes to the meetup will be able to submit a T-shirt design, as well as sign up to receive a T-shirt at the last meetup. We'll be releasing more details as we get them.

Feel free to come anytime, but the pizza will be colder the longer you wait. ;)

Take a look at the website, and make sure you register for the Study Jams. http://developerstudyjams.com/

Other than that, we'll see you on Thursday!

events.name: Android N Discussion
events.description:
Earlier this month on March 9th, Google surprised us by releasing the Android N Developer Preview over two months before Google I/O. We'll go over some of the new changes in N, how developers and users might be affected, and have some discussion about where the platform might be going.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: Study Jam - Android for Beginners
events.description:
We're back this week with another session of the Android for Beginners Study Jam. This week will be another "office hours" for people to catch up on their lessons and get general help. We'll also start talking about the final project (and associated swag!)

Since we're kind of in a weird scheduling area, we will have the Lesson 2 recap the next time we meet, which will be April 7th. We'll go over the final project again as well. Our final meetup will be the 21st, at which time we'll show off our final projects, and pass out T-shirts for everyone who signed up for one.

Speaking of T-shirts, if you have an idea for a design, please let me know. If we don't have a submitted design, you'll have to deal with the one I come up with.

Feel free to come anytime, but the pizza will be colder the longer you wait. ;)

Take a look at the website, and make sure you register for the Study Jams. http://developerstudyjams.com/

Other than that, we'll see you on Thursday!

events.name: Michigan DevFest 2016
events.description:
The 4th annual Michigan DevFest will be held in downtown Detroit. Please see the website for full details and ticket information: http://michigandevfest.com

Please note: you must have a ticket for this event. See the website for details.

events.name: IO Extended Ann Arbor
events.description:
Come hang out with other Android developers and watch the live stream of Google I/O events. Google is sponsoring the event, so we will have food and drinks through out the entire event!

We'll start with the keynote on Wednesday at 1pm, and watch the live streamed sessions throughout the remainder of the conference. Google is showing lived streamed content at the following times, Wednesday from 1pm - 10pm, Thursday from noon - 10pm, and Friday from noon - 7pm. Feel free to arrive a little early to get food, etc. 

When there are multiple live streams, we'll be showing the most Android related talk in our main room, and something else in our smaller room.

Feel free to pop in and out. We'll have some tables setup, and you can just hang out with your laptop.

events.name: Firebase: Through the Eyes of the Tech Trek App
events.description:
An intro to Firebase, followed by a code discussion on using Firebase to build the Android A2 Tech Trek app.

Firebase includes many different capabilities, and we'll start with an overview of everything you can do with it, with a specific focus on the features we used in the A2 Tech Trek app. Finally, we'll look at some of the Android code behind the app.

About the presenters:

David Wang wrote the Android A2 Tech Trek app, and had a wonderful time integrating Firebase.

Dave Koziol configured the Firebase setup for the A2 Tech Trek apps, and also wrote the iOS app. 

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: Android Food and Drinks
events.description:
Instead of a regular meetup this month, we are going to get together to eat some food, and drink some drinks while talking about Android development. 

We've got a reservation at Grizzly Peak, but please make sure you update your reservation so we can give them accurate information on how many people are coming.  Ask for the "Google Developer Group".

You know you've been dying to get out of the office/house and do something social, so come join some other geeks for some geeky conversation. As an added bonus, yes Grizzly Peak is a Pokéstop, so every 5 minutes you can give it a spin.

Please bring some cash if possible, so we can easily split the check and not have the server hate us...

events.name: RxJava and Android
events.description:
A general introduction to RxJava, followed by some practical applications of RxJava in Android development.

"Reactive" is a major buzzword in the software development industry these days, and RxJava is one of many popular frameworks. RxJava was built out by Netflix and contributed to the open source community where it has been extended for many uses, including for use specifically in Android development. We will start with a basic introduction to RxJava and how it works. With a base of knowledge under our belts, we'll delve into some of the ways that you can leverage RxJava in Android development to make your life as a developer easier and to improve your code.

About the presenter

Scott Weber is Tech Lead on the Android team at Expedia, working out of the Expedia Ann Arbor office.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: Droidcon NYC Watch Party - Day 1
events.description:
Droidcon NYC is an Android developer conference held in New York City with a fantastic lineup of some of the biggest names in the field sharing knowledge with the community.

This year, Droidcon NYC will be live-streaming all of the presentations at the event. Did you miss out on getting a ticket before they were sold out? Travel too expensive and time consuming? Don't wait 4-6 weeks for the presentations to be made public, join us to watch the live-stream! It's always more fun to watch as a group and discuss the presentations in person.

We'll be streaming from the start of the day to the end. At each hour, we'll take a poll of those in attendance to determine which of the three or four simultaneous sessions to watch. Lunch will be provided by Arbormoon.

Thursday's line-up includes presentations from prolific open-source contributor and Square employee Jake Wharton, Android Google Developer Experts Corey Latislaw and Ryan Harter, android wizard Lisa Wray, along with a bevy of others from Google, Facebook, Genymotion, Lyft, Uber, and more!

We'd love for you to join us for whatever time you can. Come for an hour, or two, half a day, or the whole thing! However, if you can't make it, or want to stay plugged in for the time you have to be away, you can use this link for a discounted live-stream pass of your own, courtesy of the folks at Droidcon NYC.

events.name: Droidcon NYC Watch Party - Day 2
events.description:
Droidcon NYC is an Android developer conference held in New York City with a fantastic lineup of some of the biggest names in the field sharing knowledge with the community.

This year, Droidcon NYC will be live-streaming all of the presentations at the event. Did you miss out on getting a ticket before they were sold out? Travel too expensive and time consuming? Don't wait 4-6 weeks for the presentations to be made public, join us to watch the live-stream! It's always more fun to watch as a group and discuss the presentations in person.

We'll be streaming from the start of the day to the end. At each hour, we'll take a poll of those in attendance to determine which of the three or four simultaneous sessions to watch. Lunch will be provided by Arbormoon.

Friday's line-up includes presentations from all-around Android expert Mark Murphy (a.k.a CommonsWare), Android Google Developer Experts Michael Bailey, Dan Lew, and Mike Wolfson, support library wizard Chris Banes, Android design guru Nick Butcher, along with others from Square, Twitter, Trello, American Express and more!

We'd love for you to join us for whatever time you can. Come for an hour, or two, half a day, or the whole thing! However, if you can't make it, or want to stay plugged in for the time you have to be away, you can use this link for a discounted live-stream pass of your own, courtesy of the folks at Droidcon NYC.

events.name: Play with a Pixel, Learn about ConstraintLayout
events.description:
We'll have several new Pixel phones on hand to look at: get a feel for the new devices from Google and how they are different (or not?) from the Nexus line and other devices. We will also be watching the "ConstraintLayout, Inside and Out" talk from Droidcon NYC. This talk is a great introduction to how to leverage the new ConstraintLayout component in your applications and is well-suited to developers both new and veteran to the Android platform.

Afterwards, join us for a drink at the Grizzly Peak (or some other nearby establishment).

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: Android Beacons
events.description:
This talk is an introduction to beacon technologies for Android devices. We'll look at what types of beacons are out there to use, such as RadBeacons and Estimotes. We'll also discuss the different types of beacon protocols available to those beacons: Eddystone and AltBeacon. We'll walk through exactly how each of these protocols work and how to implement them into your application using either Google's Proximity Beacon API coupled with Nearby Messages API and also with the AltBeacon library. So join us for the ins and outs of beacons on Android to better your user's location and proximity experiences.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

About Speaker

Jake VanAssche is a Software Engineer at Arbormoon Software Inc. focusing on developing Android mobile applications. He recently got his Master's degree in Computer Science from Wayne State and has a Bachelor's degree in Software Engineering from the University of Detroit Mercy.

events.name: Build a chat app together! (Part 1)
events.description:
This month Todd DeLand starts a multi-part series of presentations on building a geo-location based chat app. The series starts with a basic Firebase realtime chat demo, and builds upon it in subsequent presentations to integrate location based filtering, maps, and notifications.

Feel free to bring your laptop and code along with Todd!

By the end of the first night, the group will have built a basic chat app together. 

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

About the presenter

Todd DeLand is a software engineer, and father from Ann Arbor. He works at Above the Treeline primarily using .NET, and in his spare time on various Android projects. He enjoys keeping up on technology and finding ways to integrate it with daily life.

events.name: Build a chat app together! (Part 2)
events.description:
This month Todd DeLand continues with part 2 of this series of presentations on building a geo-location based chat app. Last month, we got a basic Firebase realtime chat demo up and running. This month we will build on that, integrating location based filtering.

Feel free to bring your laptop and code along with Todd! There is no requirement to have attended the first session.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

About the presenter

Todd DeLand is a software engineer, and father from Ann Arbor. He works at Above the Treeline primarily using .NET, and in his spare time on various Android projects. He enjoys keeping up on technology and finding ways to integrate it with daily life.

events.name: The 5th Annual Michigan GDG DevFest
events.description:
A ticket is required for this event. Early bird tickets are on sale till April 2 for $40/student and $75/professional. The Ann Arbor and Detroit Google Developer Groups are teaming up to bring you our 5th annual Michigan GDG DevFest on Saturday, April 22nd, 2017 in Grand Circus' offices in downtown Detroit.

This year we are excited to have great speakers like:

• Dave Mehi from Google discussing the Google Cloud Platform

• David Smith from SPLT discussing why SPLT went with React Native to build their Android App

• Kyle Paul from Phisionary explaining how to use Firebase in all of your projects

• Shriyash Jalukar sharing how to make Chrome Extensions in 30 minutes

Included with ticket price is breakfast, lunch, snack and a great day of learning and networking with developers from the local software development community.

Want to buy a ticket? Head over here: https://goo.gl/0LLSgk

Want more info? Head over here: https://gdgmichigandevfest.com

events.name: Google I/O Extended Day 1
events.description:
Come hang out with other Android developers and watch the live stream of Google I/O events. 

We'll start with the keynote on Wednesday at 1pm, and watch the live streamed sessions throughout the remainder of the conference. Google is showing lived streamed content at the following times, Wednesday from 1pm - 10pm, Thursday from 11:30am - 10:30pm, and Friday from 11:30am - 7:30pm. Please RSVP for each day you will attend.

When there are multiple live streams, we'll be showing the most Android related talk in our main room, and something else in our smaller room.

Google is providing food for lunch, dinner and snacks.

Feel free to pop in and out. We'll have some tables setup, and you can just hang out with your laptop. 

We created an event for each day so that we would have a better idea of how much food to have.  Please RSVP for each day you plan to attend.

events.name: Introduction to Google Machine Learning APIs
events.description:
The great thing about machine learning nowadays is that you do not have to be an expert in the field to start integrating machine learning into your projects. This talk will give a high-level overview of Google Machine Learning APIs, including Google Cloud ML APIs and Tensorflow. There will be demos and examples of what these APIs are actually capable of creating. Resources for people interested in Machine Learning will also be given. Many of these APIs and resources are very easy to use and will make adding machine learning to your projects relatively quick and easy. We will also discuss on a high-level what machine learning is and concepts like classifiers, training data, and testing data. 

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

About Speaker

Harry Wang is currently working as a Software Engineering intern for Arbormoon Software this summer. He is a rising sophomore pursuing a degree in Computer Science at the University of Michigan College of Engineering. Harry is apart of the GEMS Lab at U of M, a research group interested in applied machine learning and graph mining. Currently, he is working on a study of graph partitioning/clustering methods.

events.name: Android Things: The Story so Far...
events.description:
The Internet of Things(IoT) boom is coming. 34 billion devices will be connected to the internet in 2020, according to Business Insider. Of those 34 billion, IoT devices will account for up to 70% if estimates are correct. 

Ronald Daugherty will teach you how to get started with your own IoT project using the Android Things platform. Android Things lets you build professional, mass-market products on a trusted platform, without previous knowledge of embedded system design

Speaker Bio: Ronald Daugherty has spent the last seven years modding Android phones. Currently, he works as an Android Software Engineering Intern at Arbormoon while studying Software Engineering at University of Michigan Dearborn.

Pizza and pop sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

events.name: From Java to Kotlin
events.description:
Convert the Firebase Friendly Chat (Java) app to Kotlin. Bring your computer with Android Studio 3.0 to explore Kotlin in our interactive meet up.

Get the Java code from github.com/rmesquit/friendlychat-android

Get the latest Android Studio from https://developer.android.com/studio/preview/index.html

Agenda:

6:30pm

• Pizza and pop sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc.

• Download Java code

7:00pm 

• Convert to Kotlin

• Review and Debug issues 

• Discuss Kotlin concepts

About Speaker:

Rod has been building things since his dad taught him how to solder the wiring of his childhood home in Brazil. He moved to the US in 2011 and decided to build something that improves his English. As a Windows pc owner, learning Android was the logic way to go. He built his first useful Android app to help increase his vocabulary. It inspired him to pursue a career as a software engineer with Arbormoon Software, Inc. You can learn more about him from www.rodrigo.today

events.name: Tutorial: Deep Neural Networks using TensorFlow
events.description:
In this 90 minute tutorial, you will learn to write a Deep Neural Network using TensorFlow to recognize handwritten digits. Please bring a laptop with TensorFlow version 1.3 or higher installed. You can find installation instructions on www.tensorflow.org.  This tutorial is taught at the beginner level, and is intended for folks new to Machine Learning. If you'd like to preview some of the exercises we'll explore, you can find them at https://github.com/random-forests/tensorflow-workshop.

Josh Gordon works as a Developer Advocate for TensorFlow at Google. He's passionate about teaching, and has over a decade of Machine Learning experience to share. You can find him on YouTube and Twitter. 

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software at 6:00, with the presentation starting at 6:30.

NOTE: This is a special day, special start time, and a special presenter.

events.name: Google Announcement
events.description:
Google will be announcing a new phone and other interesting products October 4th. 

Join fellow Google Developer Group Ann Arbor Android Developers for lunch and refreshments at Arbormoon's offices while we watch the announcement and discuss the implications. 

Will there be a new Pixel phone? Funny you should ask...

events.name: Rolling your own: When and how to replicate commonly used android libraries
events.description:
We'll discuss several popular android libraries which make development more efficient and robust, including Dagger, RxJava, and Room.  For many use cases, these libraries provide great functionality out of the box and provide great flexibility.  There are, however, distinct reasons you should know how to 'roll your own' implementations of these libraries; simplification, flexibility and control, understanding what's under-the-hood, and team dynamics.  We'll talk about these reasons and go over demo code to illustrate the library implementations.

Mike Allon graduated from Michigan State in 2012 with a BS in Computer Engineering.  He worked as an Android engineer at Compuware, and later became the mobile team lead at Dynatrace.  More recently, he worked as a senior Android developer at Target in Minneapolis, where he helped build their flagship mobile app and lead the Android development for the Indoor Location BLE/VLC team.  He is currently working in Detroit as a co-founder of MySwimPro, a mobile fitness application for swimmers.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software (http://www.arbormoon.com/) at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: Android Code Lab
events.description:
The Android Code Lab is your opportunity to start, join, or share a project with your Android compatriots. No experience required.

We take over the Arbormoon Software (downtown Ann Arbor) offices for a few hours to talk about what’s new with Android and associated topics. 

This is a BYOC event. Bring Your Own Computer. 

This event will be co-located with an Apple Cocoa Code Lab, and you are free to try different platforms or just stick with Android folks

events.name: Mobile Code Lab
events.description:
The Mobile Code Lab is your opportunity to start, join, or share a project with your fellow mobile developers. No experience required.

We take over the Arbormoon Software offices in downtown Ann Arbor for a few hours to talk about what’s new in mobile. 

This is a BYOC event. Bring Your Own Computer. 

This event will be co-located with the Ann Arbor CocoaHeads Mobile Code lab, and you are free to try different platforms or just stick with Android folks.

events.description:
If you are just getting started developing for Android (or haven't done it in a while), please follow this link (https://developer.android.com/studio/index.html) to download the latest Android IDE (Android Studio).

How to enter the building on a Saturday: The main entrance door is facing N. Ashley St (see map below); however, if it is locked you'll need to go around the block (W Ann St), enter the parking lot behind our building, and look for the lower stairwell (East side) near the wooden tables.

events.name: 2017 Review and Sharing
events.description:
What an exciting 2017 it’s been! We’ve seen Android Studio 3.0 with first-party Kotlin support, the full launch of 8.0 Oreo and the Pixel 2, as well as many other big news stories. Let’s rewind through 2017’s news stories, discuss top headlines, and how they affect us as Android developers. This will be an open format, so bring your own news stories to share as well. We’ll also devote some time to allow attendees to share tips and tricks that they’ve learned this year so we can be more productive in 2018!

This meeting will be lead by Jingran "David" Wang, a Senior Android Software Engineer working on projects for Arbormoon Software, Inc.

The meeting will start at 6:30 with pizza and networking sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc, and the presentation portion of the meeting will begin at 7pm.  Please RSVP so we have an accurate count for food.

events.name: Build Something New With Amazing People! Local Hack Day @ Arbormoon
events.description:
This event is brought to you by GitHub, Arbormoon Software, and MLH!

• Sign Up with this link to receive digital goodies: https://hackday.mlh.io/annarbor

• What we'll do
Local Hack Day is a 12 hour hack day that brings together the local hacker community to celebrate building awesome technology.

• What to bring
Bring your computer, enthusiasm, and lots of curiosity!

• Android Developers

events.name: Intro to VR using Unity and the Daydream View
events.description:
Join us to learn how to develop your own Virtual Reality application! We will be using the Unity game engine to create a basic application that utilizes the Daydream View and its controls, in combination with your Android phone. This is a beginners talk and we will step through the basics, so everyone is welcome.

The first 25 participants that sign up and have a supported device will be eligible to receive a free Daydream View! You must have a supported device listed here to get the free Daydream View: https://vr.google.com/daydream/smartphonevr/phones/

Come immerse yourself in the world of virtual reality!

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software (http://www.arbormoon.com/) at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: Google Cloud Study Jam
events.description:
Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin?

Join us for our Cloud Study Jam! Together we'll work through three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs, then you will get free access to the next quest so you can finish this series of labs at home to get a Google-hosted badge for your online profile. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Docker and Kubernetes or Scientific Data Processing (Big Data), which will earn you additional badges.

Join this meetup to get official Google training, a $70+ value, free of charge.
(No need to create a Google Cloud Platform account or register with a credit card)

Bring a laptop (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed.

Agenda:

2:00pm: Three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs

3:30pm: Break

4:00pm: Intro to Docker or Scientific Data Processing lab

5:00pm: Event ends
events.how_to_find_us: Go around to the back of the building and enter from the lower stairwell.

events.name: Detecting Cancer with TensorFlow
events.description:
Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software (http://www.arbormoon.com/) at 1:30, with the presentation on Detecting Cancer with TensorFlow by Josh Gordon starting at 2:00.

A deep dive into recent work in medical imaging, where TensorFlow was used to assist physicians diagnose disease. I'll cover both the technology - and importantly - the problem solving process of thoughtfully applying it to solve a meaningful problem. At the end, I'll close with my favorite educational resources you can use to learn more about this important area. Josh Gordon works on the TensorFlow team at Google, and teaches Deep Learning at Pace University. He has over a decade of machine learning experience to share. You can find him on YouTube (goo.gl/KewA03) and Twitter (@random_forests).
