events.name: Google I/O Recap
events.description:
GDG Co-organizers David Wang and Todd DeLand headed out to Google I/O earlier this month. Come join them and others who attended either physically or virtually to talk about the exciting developments that happened at this years conference. Todd and David will each talk about the highlights of the conference from their personal perspective.

David has been developing Android apps since 2010 and has experience working with many technologies in the mobile space. He has been attending Google I/O since 2014.

Todd is a software engineer, and father from Ann Arbor. He works at Arbormoon Software doing backend and Android projects. He enjoys keeping up on technology and finding ways to integrate it with daily life.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software (http://www.arbormoon.com/) at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: Ann Arbor Tech Trek
events.description:
Ann Arbor Tech Trek is a free community event and a terrific opportunity to see the real gems located inside the doors of many area tech companies. It’s also a chance to see what’s unique about downtown Ann Arbor.

Leading technology companies will open their doors to the public and showcase their latest innovations. Whether you’re a job seeker, student, professional, or someone curious about the Ann Arbor tech community, anyone is welcome to attend.

Each stop on the trek will create a fun, educational experience that reflects each company’s unique culture. Those on the tour will also enjoy refreshments, prizes, t-shirts, and giveaways — while supplies last.

Tech Trek is a win-win for companies, community, and a great way for the youth to explore possible career paths.

App
Arbormoon Software is proud to have built an "Ann Arbor Tech" app which you can use as a digital map for this years trek, as well as to find out details about specific companies and plan you trip by favoriting the companies you'd like to visit.

New for 2018!
We’re closing down Washington Street between 5th Ave and Division to showcase the latest in autonomous and connected vehicles. Starting at noon, you’ll discover the future of transportation — from self-driving shuttles to leading-edge connected car technology. Be sure to check out Live @ Tech Trek presented by Bank of Ann Arbor taking place from noon–7 p.m.

Registration is required to attend. Register now at : https://www.eventbrite.com/e/a2-tech-360-presents-tech-trek-tech-talk-2018-tickets-44260663837

During the trek, job seekers can visit the Talent Terrace for career advice and targeted job searches. Check out the SPARK job portal , powered by TrueJob, or find it in the "Ann Arbor Tech" app.

events.name: Beyond Hello World: Flutter at a deeper level
events.description:
Join us for a guest lecture from Scott Stoll, co-owner of the Flutter study group and co-creator of the Flutter Zone podcast. Flutter is the open-source fully-featured cross-platform mobile development platform. Topics covered include:
(1) Comparisons to Android, iOS, and the React Native view and render systems.
(2) A brief background of the Dart language.
(3) Integration with the underlying platform (Android/iOS).
(4) Flutter in the Fuchsia OS.

This month's meetup is sponsored by Arbormoon Software, Inc <http://www.arbormoon.com>;. They'll be providing pizza and drinks at 6:30pm, and our main talk will begin at 7pm.

events.name: Learnings from 3 years of Kotlin in production
events.description:
PLEASE NOTE: NEW LOCATION! Arbormoon has moved to 120 E. Huron.
===================

Kotlin was first added to the Expedia Android app codebase in early 2015. It wasn't always a smooth path, but 3 years later, the majority of the app is written in Kotlin, and the team is happier and more productive than ever!

We will talk a little bit about our journey to Kotlintown*, as well as discuss some of the things we've learned along the way. The good, the bad, and the ugly.

* (with thanks to Christina Lee and Huyen Tue Dao for the excellent name)
===================

Presenters:
Scott Weber, Android Lead @ Expedia
David Cheng, Android Developer @ Expedia
===================

events.name: Flutter Study Jam Kickoff (1/4)
events.description:
Flutter is Google’s mobile app SDK for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source.

Want to get started on building Flutter apps?

Join us for our Flutter Study Jam! Together we'll work through the Flutter Udacity Course prepared by Google instructors. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Flutter and build a Flutter app while learning the fundamentals.

Bring a laptop! The course will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, the laptop should have Flutter installed on it prior to starting the study jam to save time. Windows/Linux/Mac would all be fine. Check out: https://flutter.io/get-started/install/

Agenda:
6:30 pm: Pizza, set-up assistance
7:00 pm: Flutter Udacity Course Introduction
7:10 pm: Udacity Course Lesson 1
8:00 pm: Break
8:10 pm: Udacity Course Lesson 1 continued
9:00 pm: Event ends

This is a 4-part study jam. We will hold the first session during our normal GDG meetup, and then two Saturday Office Hour sessions. Our final session will be at the 2018 Michigan DevFest in Detroit. Be on the lookout for more details soon!

Schedule:
August 23 (Thu): Kickoff and Lesson 1
September 29 (Sat): Office Hours
October 27 (Sat): Office Hours
November 10 (Sat): Wrap-up at DevFest

events.name: The 6th Annual Michigan GDG DevFest
events.description:
A ticket is required for this event. Tickets are on sale till Nov 3 for $30/student and $60/professional. After the 3rd they will be $40/$75. The Ann Arbor and Detroit Google Developer Groups are teaming up to bring you our 6th annual Michigan GDG DevFest on Saturday, November 10, 2018 in Grand Circus' offices in downtown Detroit.

This year we are excited to have great speakers like:
Keith Bourne - I'm going to do machine learning with GCP! Ok, but how?
Godfrey Nolan - Counting Sheep with Drones & AI

Included with ticket price is breakfast, lunch, snack and a great day of learning and networking with developers from the local software development community.

Want to buy a ticket? Head over here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-michigan-google-developers-devfest-2018-tickets-48916211706

Want more info? Head over here: https://michigandevfest.com

events.name: Flutter Live Viewing Party and Codelab
events.description:
Join us for Flutter Live on December 4th to experience the latest from Flutter, Google’s free and open source SDK for building high-quality native iOS and Android apps from a single codebase. Presented from the Science Museum in London, we will be watching the delayed livestream here in Ann Arbor. The keynote is 1.5 hours long, so we will be starting promptly at 6:30.

8:00 - Flutter Codelab

events.description:

If you are involved with the local tech community in some way (developer, designer, founder, sales, support, etc), please consider yourself invited. events.name: Google Kubernetes Engine
events.description:
Kubernetes Engine is a managed, production-ready environment for deploying containerized applications. It brings Google's latest innovations in developer productivity, resource efficiency, automated operations, and open source flexibility to accelerate your time to market.

Launched in 2015, Kubernetes Engine builds on Google’s experience of running services like Gmail and YouTube in containers for over 12 years. Kubernetes Engine allows you to get up and running with Kubernetes in no time, by completely eliminating the need to install, manage, and operate your own Kubernetes clusters.

Gary Coburn, Google Cloud Customer Engineer will take the group through Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) and GKE Local.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software (http://www.arbormoon.com/) at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.

events.name: TensorFlow Dev Summit Live Keynote Viewing Party
events.description:
Please note! There are TWO versions of this event on the same day - a 12/noon version and a 6pm version. This is the NOON version. You are welcome to attend both, but please check to make sure you are signing up for the right one so we can get a proper head count for the food!

ALSO! This event is co-hosted with the Ann Arbor Machine Learning meetup group (https://www.meetup.com/Machine-Learning-Data-Science-and-Industry/). Please RSVP at one or the other of the groups, but not both!

Join us for TensorFlow Dev Summit 2019 (https://www.tensorflow.org/dev-summit), bringing together a diverse mix of machine learning users from around the world for highly technical talks, demos, and conversations with the TensorFlow team and community.

Event topics are likely to touch on:
TensorFlow 2.0: Best practices + Autograph
TensorFlow Lite
TensorFlow.js
Swift for TensorFlow
TFX: TensorFlow in production with Data Validation, Model Analysis, and Serving
Groundbreaking ML research using TensorFlow and use cases from around the world
...and some new items to be announced later!

This is the premier event focused specifically on TensorFlow, Google's widely popular open source machine learning framework for high performance numerical computation. Its flexible architecture allows easy deployment of computation across a variety of platforms (CPUs, GPUs, TPUs), and from desktops to clusters of servers to mobile and edge devices. Originally developed by researchers and engineers from the Google Brain team within Google’s AI organization, it comes with strong support for machine learning and deep learning and the flexible numerical computation core is used across many other scientific domains.

Keith Bourne, founder of Gradient Valley, will be the one to hit the power on the TV and connect his laptop so we can watch the actual Keynote from Sunnydale, CA. But afterwards, Keith will guide a discussion about the topics discussed at the event and what it means to future machine learning development.

Please join us for food and refreshments at 12:00 noon, sponsored by Google and GDG. The keynote is scheduled to start at 12:30pm.

Schedule:
12:00pm - Food and networking!
12:30pm - Livestream of Keynote from Sunnydale, CA
1:30pm-2:00pm discussion about Keynote topics

events.name: IWD, Code: Debugging the Gender Gap
events.description:
In a (belated) celebration of International Women's Day 2019, we will host a screening of Code: Debugging the Gender Gap along with some discussions from our local Tech-Inclusive (https://www.meetup.com/Tech-Inclusive/) community.

We'll kick the event off with pizza and networking, and start the movie at 7pm with some popcorn. We hope you'll join us as we try to learn more about this important issue.

This documentary exposes the dearth of American female and minority software engineers and explores the reasons for this gender gap and digital divide. The film highlights breakthrough efforts that are producing more diverse programmers and shows how this critical gap can be closed. CODE asks: what would society gain from having more women and minorities code and how do we get there?

events.name: Everyday Animations In Android
events.description:
Animation is often seen as a nice-to-have or gratuitous in software projects. In truth, animations actually exist to improve an app's user experience. Animations help users understand state changes, guide them to notice meaningful information, gather focus to a required action, or express relationships between UI elements. This session examines traditional techniques using property and drawable animations, as well as the new MotionLayout introduced at Google I/O 2018. These techniques can expand content, display state, move elements, and highlight important controls. Properly executed animation effects are applicable to buttons, lists, and images in any Android app, taking an app's user experience from good to great.

A long time resident of metro Detroit, Dr. Truxall has been slinging code for a living since 1995, working with enterprise web technologies, modeling business processes, and building public web sites and mobile apps for some of the largest companies in North America. Always an enthusiast for troubleshooting systems, Trux has rescued numerous troubled applications and improved their performance. Co-author of the book Android Best Practices, he speaks at local conferences and user groups. Currently Trux is working in mobility at Perspecta, bringing digital services to the public sector.

Food will be provided by Arbormoon Software (http://www.arbormoon.com/) at 6:30, with the presentation starting at 7:00.
